user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of alloc:
```c
static int alloc(void)
{
	void *ptr;

	ptr = metal_allocate_memory(1000);
	if (!ptr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "failed to allocate memory\n");
		return errno;
	}

	metal_free_memory(ptr);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function alloc:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided target function alloc and the related macro definition. There is no use of memcmp or any other raw memory-comparison of strings in the alloc function or in the metal_log macro expansion shown. The only string literal appears in the metal_log call, but that is passed to metal_fmt and a log handler — neither of which is defined here and no memcmp call is present in the provided fragments. There are also no calls that pass C strings into memcmp-like operations in the shown code. Therefore, based on the supplied code and macro, there are no code fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 and nothing here needs further investigation for memcmp-on-null-terminated-strings. (If metal_fmt or the log handler implementations — not provided — use memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, those implementations would need review; they are outside the supplied fragments.)
